TopicTitle: Could sulfur dioxide magma can be used as a power source for Ionian bases?

Articles.Content:
Gah, i have another space-related question for you guys.

Could sulfur dioxide magma can be used as a power source for bases on the Galilean moon, Io, as the title suggests?
I'm guess yes, because there is enough energy there for it to be ejecting in large plumes from the surface (basically volcanoes). The heat should be enough for good geothermal power.

Sulfur dioxide is not magma. It's gas and it's dissolved in magma. When magma reaches close to the surface where the pressure is lower, gases froth it up, like when you open a bottle of carbonated beverage or when a diver with nitrogen-saturated blood climbs fast to the surface.

It would be very hard to use it, almost impossible. It's too violent, it has low thermal conductivity and is unpredictable, and you want steady and predictable source of power.

lajoswinkler, You are extrapolating too much between Earth and Io. Google IO and you will see that it is essentially covered by S compounds. Therefore, it is likely that "volcanic degassing" in Io is mostly sulfur. As for use, it's not a mater of thermal conductivity or predictability. Steam from volcanic centres on earth can be used to produce energy. The major challenge in Io would be technical and material science. Sulfur is highly corrosive to metals so any part in contact with the sulfur would need to be made of ceramics. But that is a trivial thing given that if we manage to get to Io to build anything on there is already the major hurdle. Conversely what would you like to go to Io? Ganymede seems a much better place to try anything! It has water! lots of it and I'm sure there is a temperature gradient between the ice surface and the liquid water under that thick icy crust. You can probably build a thermal pump that takes advantage of that...

I'm not extrapolating anything. Sulfur dioxide has constant properties. Chemical properties don't change depending on where the matter is.

Aside from the fact that sulfur dioxide is not magma (molten rocks), using a gas that tends to erupt violently from a planetary body would be madness. Not only its thermal conductivity is poor (it's a gas), it would rip apart any infrastructure laid on the terrain. I'd rather sink some heat exchangers into molten sulfur, gently flowing from the depths.
